member.summary: Recompresses image data using zlib/deflate compression method and specified compression quality.
member.param: The quality to use in Deflate encoder.

remarks.para: The Deflate quality value should be between 0 and 9 inclusive.
The quality value of 9 gives best compression.
This method throws when used on an inline image. You can check property before invoking this method.

member.name: M:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfImage.RecompressWithGroup3Fax
member.summary: Recompresses image data using Group 3 CCITT facsimile (fax) encoding.

remarks.para: Using Group 3 CCITT facsimile (fax) encoding will cause image data to be converted to bilevel (black-and-white) format if necessary.
The threshold level is set to default value (189) during recompression.
This method throws when used on an inline image. You can check property before invoking this method.

member.overloads: Recompresses image data using Group 3 CCITT facsimile (fax) encoding.

member.name: M:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfImage.RecompressWithGroup3Fax(System.Int32)
member.summary: Recompresses image data using Group 3 CCITT facsimile (fax) encoding and specified threshold level.
member.param: The threshold level.

remarks.para: Using Group 3 CCITT facsimile (fax) encoding will cause image data to be converted to bilevel (black-and-white) format if necessary.
The threshold level is used to decide which pixels are white and which are black when converting image data to black-and-white format.
The threshold level value should be between 0 and 255 inclusive. A threshold value 0 means that library should use midpoint between most light and dark pixels as a threshold value.

If the image contains some scanned document or other data with mostly white background pixels and mostly black foreground pixels then threshold level of 189 or higher is recommended to preserve most of the data.
This method throws when used on an inline image. You can check property before invoking this method.

member.name: M:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfImage.ReplaceWith(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Replaces image with the image in the stream.
member.param: The stream with an image.

remarks.para: This method replaces all occurrences of the image within the document. If the original image was used on several pages, then the new image will be used in the same places of the same pages.
The stream should contain a complete image encoded with one of the supported image compression schemes. This method won't work with only raster bytes or any other partial contents.
This method throws when used on an inline image. You can check property before invoking this method.

Replacing an image can cause unexpected and/or unpleasant visual results. For example, image masking effects can be broken if you replace a mask image or an image that has a mask. Usually, it is undesirable to replace an image with a new image that has very different size and/or proportions.

member.overloads: Replaces image with the new one.

This method throws when used on an inline image. You can check property before invoking this method.

Replacing an image can cause unexpected and/or unpleasant visual results. For example, image masking effects can be broken if you replace a mask image or an image that has a mask. Usually, it is undesirable to replace an image with a new image that has very different size and/or proportions.

This method throws when used on an inline image. You can check property before invoking this method.

Replacing an image can cause unexpected and/or unpleasant visual results. For example, image masking effects can be broken if you replace a mask image or an image that has a mask. Usually, it is undesirable to replace an image with a new image that has very different size and/or proportions.

member.name: T:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfImageFrame
member.summary: Class for one frame of an image and its options. The options specify how the frame should be processed before adding it to .

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfImageFrame.RecompressAlways
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this frame MUST be recompressed before adding to document.
member.value: true if this frame MUST be recompressed before adding to document; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: If this value is true then this frame will be recompressed using compression scheme specified by the property before adding to document. If this value is false then library will try to add this frame to document without modifications. Please note that frame may be recompressed even when this value is false if the frame contains image in one of the formats unsupported by the PDF.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfImageFrame.OutputCompression
member.summary: Gets or sets the compression to use for this frame's image data during recompression.
member.value: The compression to use for this frame's image data during recompression.

remarks.para: The image data gets recompressed if property is true or if the frame contains image data in one of the formats unsupported by the PDF.
Some compression scheme are lossy (i.e. some data may be lost during compression) or require image data to be converted to black-and-white format.
The compression methods is not supported yet.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfImageFrame.JpegQuality
member.summary: Gets or sets the JPEG quality.
member.value: The quality to use in JPEG encoder.

remarks.para: The JPEG quality value should be between 1 and 100 inclusive.
The quality value of 100 preserves most details but produces biggest output.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfImageFrame.Jpeg2000CompressionRatio
member.summary: Gets or sets the JPEG 2000 compression ratio.
member.value: The compression ratio to use in JPEG 2000 encoder.

remarks.para: The JPEG 2000 compression ratio should not be less than 1.
The compression ratio equal to 1 causes lossless compression but produces biggest output. The larger compression ratio values cause smaller outputs in expense of image detail.
The compression ratio of N means "compress N times".

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfImageFrame.DeflateQuality
member.summary: Gets or sets the Deflate quality.
member.value: The quality to use in Deflate encoder.

remarks.para: The Deflate quality value should be between 0 and 9 inclusive.
The quality value of 9 gives best compression.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfImageFrame.ThresholdLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the threshold level.
member.value: The threshold level.

remarks.para: The threshold level is used to decide which pixels are white and which are black when converting image data to black-and-white format.
The threshold level value should be between 0 and 255 inclusive. A threshold value 0 means that library should use midpoint between most light and dark pixels as a threshold value.

If the frame contains some scanned document or other data with mostly white background pixels and mostly black foreground pixels then threshold level of 189 or higher is recommended to preserve most of the data.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPage.MediaBox
member.summary: Gets or sets the media box of the page.
member.value: The media box of the page expressed in PDF's default user space coordinate system. In default user space the positive X axis extends horizontally to the right and the positive Y axis extends vertically upward.

remarks.para: Default value: { 0, 0, , }

The media box defines the boundaries of the physical medium on which the page is to be printed. It may include any extended area surrounding the finished page for bleed, printing marks, or other such purposes. It may also include areas close to the edges of the medium that cannot be marked because of physical limitations of the output device. Content falling outside this boundary can safely be discarded without affecting the meaning of the PDF file.
Changing the value of this property resets values of other page boxes (, , , ). Their values will be reset to this property's value.
Additionally, changing the value of this property resets values of , , , properties.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPage.CropBox
member.summary: Gets or sets the crop box of the page.
member.value: The crop box of the page expressed in PDF's default user space coordinate system. In default user space the positive X axis extends horizontally to the right and the positive Y axis extends vertically upward.

remarks.para: Default value: Equal to
The crop box defines the region to which the contents of the page are to be clipped (cropped) when displayed or printed.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPage.BleedBox
member.summary: Gets or sets the bleed box of the page.
member.value: The bleed box of the page expressed in PDF's default user space coordinate system. In default user space the positive X axis extends horizontally to the right and the positive Y axis extends vertically upward.

remarks.para: Default value: Equal to

The bleed box defines the region to which the contents of the page should be clipped when output in a production environment. This may include any extra bleed area needed to accommodate the physical limitations of cutting, folding, and trimming equipment. The actual printed page may include printing marks that fall outside the bleed box.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPage.TrimBox
member.summary: Gets or sets the trim box of the page.
member.value: The trim box of the page expressed in PDF's default user space coordinate system. In default user space the positive X axis extends horizontally to the right and the positive Y axis extends vertically upward.

remarks.para: Default value: Equal to

The trim box defines the intended dimensions of the finished page after trimming. It may be smaller than the to allow for production-related content, such as printing instructions, cut marks, or color bars.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPage.ArtBox
member.summary: Gets or sets the art box of the page.
member.value: The art box of the page expressed in PDF's default user space coordinate system. In default user space the positive X axis extends horizontally to the right and the positive Y axis extends vertically upward.

remarks.para: Default value: Equal to
The art box defines the extent of the pageвЂ™s meaningful content (including potential white space) as intended by the pageвЂ™s creator.

member.name: T:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPattern
member.summary: Base class for all PDF pattern classes.

member.name: T:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPen
member.summary: Class that encapsulates properties of a related to stroking operations.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPen.DashPattern
member.summary: Gets or sets the line dash pattern.
member.value: Line dash pattern.
member.remarks:
The line dash pattern controls the pattern of dashes and gaps used to stroke paths.
Default value: a solid line.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPen.EndCap
member.summary: Gets or sets the value specifying the shape of the endpoints for any open path that is stroked.
member.value: The value specifying the shape of the endpoints for any open path that is stroked.
member.remarks: Default value: .

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPen.LineJoin
member.summary: Gets or sets the value specifying the shape of joints between connected segments of a stroked path.
member.value: The value specifying the shape of joints between connected segments of a stroked path.
member.remarks: Default value: .

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPen.MiterLimit
member.summary: Gets or sets the miter limit of this pen.
member.value: The miter limit.

remarks.para: When two line segments meet at a sharp angle and mitered joins have been specified as the line join style, it is possible for the miter to extend far beyond the thickness of the line stroking the path. The miter limit imposes a maximum on the ratio of the miter length to the line width. When the limit is exceeded, the join is converted from a to a .
Default value: 10.0, for a miter cutoff below approximately 11.5 degrees.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPen.Width
member.summary: Gets or sets the width of this pen.
member.value: The width of this pen.
member.remarks:
This parameter specifies the thickness of the line used to stroke a path. It is a non-negative number expressed in user space units; stroking a path entails painting all points whose perpendicular distance from the path in user space is less than or equal to half the line width.
A width of 0 denotes the thinnest line that can be rendered at device resolution: 1 device pixel wide. However, some devices cannot reproduce 1-pixel lines, and on high-resolution devices, they are nearly invisible. Since the results of rendering such zero-width lines are device-dependent, their use is not recommended.
Default value: 1.0

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPen.Pattern
member.summary: Gets or sets the pattern to be used for stroking.
member.value: The pattern to be used for stroking.
member.remarks:
Default value: null.
Setting this property to an instance of a colored causes the property to be set to null. Setting this property to an instance of an uncolored causes the property to be set to the default color of the uncolored tiling pattern's underlying color space if color space of current pen color do not match the underlying color space of the uncolored pattern being set. If color space of current pen color and the underlying color space of the uncolored tiling pattern being set do match then current pen color won't be changed. Setting this property to null causes the property to be set to default RGB color if current pattern was an instance of a colored .

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPen.Color
member.summary: Gets or sets the color to be used for stroking.
member.value: The current color to be used for stroking.
member.remarks:
Default value: black.
Setting this property may affect the property. If is an instance of a colored then it will be set to null. If is an instance of an uncolored and the color space of a color being set do not match the underlying color space of that uncolored pattern then will be set to null. If color space of a color being set and the underlying color space of the current uncolored tiling pattern do match then current pattern won't be changed.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPen.Opacity
member.summary: (PDF 1.4) Gets or sets the opacity value in percent to be used for stroking operations.
member.remarks:
Opacity value ranges from 0 (fully transparent) to 100 (fully opaque).
Default value: 100.
member.value: The opacity value in percent for stroking operations.

member.summary: Returns a that represents this instance.

member.summary: Gets the miter limit of this pen.

member.remarks: When two line segments meet at a sharp angle and mitered joins have been specified as the line join style, it is possible for the miter to extend far beyond the thickness of the line stroking the path. The miter limit imposes a maximum on the ratio of the miter length to the line width. When the limit is exceeded, the join is converted from a to a .

member.summary: Gets the size of the page area occupied by the text of this chunk.
member.value: The size of the page area occupied by the text of this chunk.

remarks.para: The size corresponds to the width and the height of the rectangle.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfTextData.Bounds
member.summary: Gets the bounds of this chunk's text on the page.
member.value: The bounds of this chunk's text on the page.

remarks.para: The bounds correspond to the smallest rectangle enclosing the text chunk. The bounding rectangle has the same orientation as the page. It means that even if the chunk is rotated or otherwise transformed (check property) the bounding box will retain it's orientation (but not necessarily size) and will still enclose all the text in the chunk.
The size of the bounding rectangle depends on , , and properties.
Note that the height of the bounding rectangle doesn't depend on the actual characters being drawn. The height is calculated using and properties and also the bounding box of .
The bounding box of a font is the smallest rectangle enclosing the shape that would result if all of the glyphs of the font were placed with their origins coincident and then filled.
Below is an example of value for a transformed text.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfTextData.Font
member.summary: Gets the font used to draw this chunk.
member.value: The font used to draw this chunk.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfTextData.FontSize
member.summary: Gets the scale factor of the font used to draw this chunk.
member.value: The scale factor of the font used to draw this chunk.

remarks.para: A font defines the glyphs for one standard size. This standard is arranged so that the nominal height of tightly spaced lines of text is 1 unit. In the default user coordinate system, this means the standard glyph size is 1 point (or 1 вЃ„ 72 inch). The standard-size font must then be scaled to be usable.

This property retrieves the scale factor used to draw the text chunk. Usually, the property retrieves values like 10, 12, 14. But the might have an arbitrary value like 1, 1000, -1, -10. It's just a scale factor.
The final height of the text chunk depends on both and properties.
For a non-transformed text the is the identity matrix (the TransformationMatrix. property is equal to true). In such a case the absolute text height is equal to Math.Abs().
For a scaled text the looks like { M11; 0; 0; M22; 0; 0 }. In such a case the absolute text height is equal to Math.Abs(.M22 * ).
For an arbitrarily transformed text the looks like { M11; M12; M21; M22; X; Y }. In such a case the absolute text height is equal to (Math.Abs() * Math.Sqrt(Math.Pow(.M21, 2) + Math.Pow(.M22, 2))).

Let's try to understand the nature of this formula. At first, the matrix { FontSize, 0, 0, FontSize, 0, 0 } is multiplied by the current (current matrix being the right multiplier). The resulting matrix is { M11 * FontSize; M12 * FontSize; M21 * FontSize; M22 * FontSize; X; Y }. Then we calculate the text height in the new transformed space. We map points (0; 0) and (0; 1) from default space to the transformed space. The result is (X; Y) and (M21 * FontSize + X; M22 * FontSize + Y), respectively. And finally we calculate the length of this vector, that is exactly the absolute text height in the transformed space: Math.Sqrt(Math.Pow(M21 * FontSize, 2) + Math.Pow(M22 * FontSize, 2)) = Math.Abs(FontSize) * Math.Sqrt(Math.Pow(M21, 2) + Math.Pow(M22, 2))
Below is an example of rotated text for which the is equal to 1.

member.value: The character spacing specified in unscaled text space units.
member.remarks: The character spacing is added to the horizontal or vertical component of each glyphвЂ™s displacement, depending on the writing mode.

member.name: M:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfTextData.GetCharacters
member.summary: Gets the collection of all characters in this chunk.
member.returns: Collection of all characters in this chunk with their bounding rectangles.

remarks.para: This method is useful when you extract text as is or by words (for example using PdfPage.). In this case you can get information about specific characters within text chunks. You may use this information to analyze text and bounds of characters.
This method is useless when you extract text by characters (using PdfPage.). In this case you will always get the same single character.

member.name: M:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfTextData.GetCharacterCodes
member.summary: Gets character codes for the chunk of text data.
member.returns: Character codes for the chunk of text data.

remarks.para: Character codes represent raw PDF string that is used to draw the text. They strictly depend on a font and font's encoding in PDF document. An attempt to use character codes with another font can lead to unpredictable result.
Use method to draw text using character codes. Make sure to set property to property of this text data.
Use method to get character codes for individual glyphs.

member.name: T:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfQuadrilateral
member.summary: A quadrilateral represented by four double precision floating-point points.

member.name: M:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfQuadrilateral.#ctor(BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfPoint[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct.
member.param: Four points representing vertices of valid quadrilateral.
member.remarks:
Order of points is important:
The same set of corners can define different concave quadrilaterals. Consider this quadrilateral: (10, 30), (30, 30), (10, 10) and (11, 12). You can simply reorder corners to define different quadrilateral: (10, 30), (10, 10), (11, 12) and (30, 30).
Quadrilaterals are used for text markup annotations (descendants of ). First and second corners of a quadrilateral define the orientation of the annotation.

member.value: A that represents the third corner of this quadrilateral.

member.value: A that represents the fourth corner of this quadrilateral.

member.summary: Gets or sets the bounding box (rectangle that defines the location of the control on the page).
member.value: The bounding box, corresponding to of the owner page.

member.value: The text displayed when the mouse hovers over the control.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfControl.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the control name.

remarks.para: In general, all controls that are children of another control must have unique names. But there is an exceptions from this rule : all controls in a group of s usually have the same name.
Control names can not contain a period.
Please use property to get a fully qualified name of the control.

member.value: The control name.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfControl.FullName
member.summary: Gets the fully qualified name of the control.

remarks.para: For a control with no parent, the partial and fully qualified names are the same. For a control that is the child of another control, the fully qualified name is formed by appending the child control's partial name to the parent's fully qualified name, separated by a period (.)

member.value: The fully qualified name of the control.

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfControl.MappingName

remarks.para: The mapping name is used when exporting form data from the document. For example, transmits (if set) instead of .

member.value: The mapping name of the control.

member.name: M:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfControl.Flatten
member.summary: Flattens this control to its parent page. In effect, replaces the control with its appearance.

remarks.para: Flattening locks control from editing. Flattening can significantly reduce file size if property is set to true.

This method flattens the control in 2 steps:
Draws control on its parent page using text and vector graphics operators.
Removes control from the document and from the PdfPage. collection of its parent page.

NOTES:
Do not use this control after successful flattening. The flattened control is detached from its document.
This method modifies PdfPage. collection so do not use method within foreach (var control in page.Controls) loop.
This method can change graphics state of the page. To avoid possible side effects, call the method right before saving of the document.

exception.para: Control does not have a parent page ( is null) or control is hidden ( is true)

member.exception: Control has a signature type ( equals to )

member.name: P:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfRadioButton.ChecksInUnison
member.summary: (PDF 1.5) Gets or sets a value indicating whether this radio button and all other radio buttons with the same export values from the same group of radio buttons should turn on and off in unison; that is if one is checked, they are all checked.
member.value: A value indicating whether this radio button and all other radio buttons with the same export values from the same group of radio buttons should turn on and off in unison; that is if one is checked, they are all checked.

remarks.para: If this property is true then all radio buttons with the same export values from the same group of radio buttons will turn on and off in unison; that is if one is checked, they are all checked. If this property is the buttons are mutually exclusive (the same behavior as HTML radio buttons).
The default value of this property is false. I.e. radio buttons are mutually exclusive by default.

member.summary: Class for a sound annotation.
member.remarks: A sound annotation is analogous to a text annotation () except that instead of a text note, it contains sound recorded from the computerвЂ™s microphone or imported from a file. When the annotation is activated, the sound is played. The annotation behaves like a text annotation in most ways, with a different icon (by default, a speaker) to indicate that it represents a sound.

member.name: T:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfTextAnnotation
member.summary: Class for a text annotation.
member.remarks: A text annotation represents a "sticky note" attached to a point in the PDF document. When closed, the annotation appears as an icon; when open, it displays a pop-up window containing the text of the note in a font and size chosen by the viewer application. Text annotations do not scale and rotate with the page; they behave as if the and properties were always set.

member.name: T:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfTrapNetworkAnnotation
member.summary: Class for a trap network annotation.
member.remarks: A trap network annotation defines the trapping characteristics for a page of a PDF document. (Trapping is the process of adding marks to a page along color boundaries to avoid unwanted visual artifacts resulting from misregistration of colorants when the page is printed.) A page may have at most one trap network annotation.

member.name: T:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfUnderlineAnnotation
member.summary: Class for a underline annotation.
member.remarks: Underline annotations appear as underlines in the text of a document. When opened, they display a pop-up window containing the text of the associated note.

member.name: T:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfWatermarkAnnotation
member.summary: Class for a watermark annotation.

remarks.para: A watermark annotation (PDF 1.6) is used to represent graphics that are expected to be printed at a fixed size and position on a page, regardless of the dimensions of the printed page.

Watermark annotations have no pop-up window or other interactive elements. When displaying a watermark annotation on-screen, viewer applications should use the dimensions of the media box as the page size so that the scroll and zoom behavior is the same as for other annotations.
Note: Since many printing devices have nonprintable margins, it is recommended that such margins be taken into consideration when positioning watermark annotations near the edge of a page.

member.name: T:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.PdfWidget

member.name: T:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.XmpSchema
member.summary: Class for an XMP schema. A schema is a set of properties. Typically, schemas may consist of properties that are relevant only for particular types of documents or for certain stages of a workflow.

member.name: M:BitMiracle.Docotic.Pdf.XmpSchema.#ctor(System.String,System.Uri)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The schema namespace prefix.
The name of the schema.

remarks.para: Metadata should not contain duplicate schemas, so the will be thrown if metadata already contains schema with specified namespace prefix.
Creation of schemas with well-known prefixes is forbidden. Please use corresponding properties of to access properties of a well-known schema.

Each schema consists of a schema name and namespace prefix. The name is a URI that serves to uniquely identify the schema. It is simply a unique string. A schema name looks like an URI (e.g. 'http://ns.adobe.com/xap/1.0/') but there might or might not be an actual Web page at the URI. The URI must obey XML namespace rules, and it should end in "/" or "#".
A schema namespace prefix is a short abbreviation for the full schema name. The prefix is used for properties in the schema.

member.overloads: Initializes a new instance of the class.
